awd_titl_txt: Building Best Practices in Infancy Research
awd_abstract_narration: This award supports the convening of a preconference meeting in advance of the International Congress of Infant Studies in New Orleans, LA on May 25, 2016.  The goal of the preconference meeting is to consider unique concerns and challenges associated with preserving best practices in infancy research to enhance replication and reproducibility.  Results from a survey of infancy researchers on their research and training practices will be disseminated, and leaders in the field will make presentations about important considerations on topics such as training, inclusion criteria, and cross-lab replications.  The meeting will culminate with a discussion among members of the Executive Committee of the International Congress of Infant Studies and the editors of the Congress' flagship journal, Infancy, regarding standards for the conduct and publication of research.  The outcomes of this meeting will have important implications for the support and preservation of robust and reliable infancy research.

por.por_cntn:
Given recent concerns about replication and reproducibility of research in psychology as a whole, and following on the heels of recent reports of questionable research practices in infancy research more specifically (Peterson, 2016), we organized a preconference workshop on building best practices in infancy research to precede ICIS, in May 2016. The goal of the preconference was to provide a starting point for crafting best practices in infancy research, and potentially ultimately establishing publication standards for research in infancy. Establishing such field level best practices is a central step toward ensuring the reproducibility and reliability of our science, and will be an important tool for helping teach new scientists about how to conduct research in this area. To that end, our preconference featured the following events:

  • A presentation by Kiley Hamlin and Jessica Sommerville on the results of a survey of commonly used practices in infancy research.
  • A presentation by Lisa Oakes on the effects of adopting different practices on a data set.
  • A presentation by John Colombo on what we can learn from clinical trials
  • A presentation my Mike Frank on the Many Babies project (a project aimed at demonstrating the replicability or non-replicability of research with infants by coordinating efforts of many labs).
  • A presentation by NSF representatives on NSF's vision for supporting replicability in the basic sciences
  • A presentation by Lisa Freund and Marita Hopmann on NIH's emerging focus on reproducibility and reliability of results.  
  • A discussion with members of the ICIS executive committee and Infancy editors on establishing standards for publishing

Over 100 participants attended the preconference. We received many positive reviews of the preconference. In addition, based on our award we were able to award 10 junior scholars travel support awards of $100 each that supported their travel to the preconference.

The impact of our preconference is already evident at a field-wide level. For example, the journal Infancy has already created a special issue on Best practices for which we (Eason, Hamlin & Sommerville, in press) submitted an article based on our presentation. Furthermore, Infancy has changed their publication standards to allow for pre-registered reports. These positive changes along such a short time frame suggest that we accomplished our main objectives - to promote and encourage discussion and consideration of issues related to replicability and reproducibility - and that our preconference activities and ensuing outcomes that stem from these activities will continue to move the field forward.

Modified by: Jessica Sommerville
